descript.abstract: World Surface Runoff (line), 1996 is a polyline theme representing levels of water surface runoff worldwide.
descript.purpose: For educational, non-commercial purposes. This dataset is appropriate for use in a GIS.
descript.supplinf:
Surface runoff is the process whereby water from rain, melted snow and ice, and surface drainage flows into channels, depressions, and the world's oceans. Its amount and regime depend on the balance of precipitation and evaporation in river basins, relief, geological structure, soil, and vegetation. Runoff causes erosion, natural drainage and dryness, and the transfer and accumulation of denudation matter. Surface runoff is distinguished from groundwater discharge, which is water that flows within the earth's crust.
The volume of water discharged by a particular river constitutes the total runoff of the watershed above that location. Because surface runoff is highly variable in time as well as space, it is recorded over many years. It can be expressed using different indexes. One of the most common indexes, and the one used in this atlas, expresses runoff as a layer of water evenly covering the land. It is calculated using the mean annual runoff in millimeters at an observation point.
The maps show watersheds as areas upstream from runoff observation stations. The runoff value for a watershed is assigned to a central point inside it rather than at the observation station.
Knowledge of runoff varies for different continents and regions. Reliable observations of runoff are available for as many as 100 to 150 years for Europe, but they average fewer years for the rest of the world. There are more than 60,000 hydrological observation stations around the world at the present time. Their density is highest in Europe and North America.

procstep.procdesc:
Absolute mean annual runoff in millimeters of water layer was calculated from observation data of hydrological stations, literature, and cartographic sources. A commonly used method of calculating runoff called the mass-balance approach was used with input from climatic data, a water balance equation, and a function of runoff coefficient, and a dryness index.
Runoff was calculated for key basins then interpolated for basins with similar characteristics such as geographical zone. In plains the key basins were chosen to represent all the factors that affect runoff formation. Where possible, they belonged to a single natural zone and had particular climatic and hydrological observations. Isolines were drawn by interpolation.
The areas of key basins are much smaller in mountains than on plains due to the more complex topography. In mountain areas, isolines were drawn by ratio of runoff and the mean altitude of a river basin. Calculated indexes and isolines were detailed by relief and other natural factors.
In poorly explored regions values for mean annual precipitation and evaporation were used to draw runoff isolines.
Runoff values of key basins were acquired by hydrological yearbooks. Mean annual values were calculated by series that cover complete runoff cycles (those with approximately equal numbers of low-water and high-water phases over several years). Short series of observations were adjusted to multi year series.
Isolines were verified with climatic maps and data as well as river runoff records. The error of mean annual runoff is less than 10 percent for about a half of the land area of the world, including the temperate belt of the northern hemisphere, the densely populated coastal areas of South America, the east coast of Australia, and east and southwest Africa. Those areas have rather dense networks of hydrological stations and long series of observations. The error is greater in regions such as Central America, Indonesia, Oceania, and the eastern part of the Amazon basin. The error is also greater for small areas compared with large ones because of the greater influence of non climatic and azonal factors.
